<a href="http://www.cnn.com/CNNI/Programs/middle.east/blog/uploaded_images/CairoOct2008-012-704650.jpg"><img style="DISPLAY: block; MARGIN: 0px auto 10px; CURSOR: hand; TEXT-ALIGN: center" alt="" src="http://www.cnn.com/CNNI/Programs/middle.east/blog/uploaded_images/CairoOct2008-012-704327.jpg" border="0" /></a><br /><div>In Egypt filming an hour-long special on the Middle East due to air in the nenxt few months, the Inside the Middle East team filed a quick spot on the financial crisis in Egypt for CNN International.</div><br /><div>The main Cairo stock index has lost over 20% over the last two sessions. But for ordinary Egyptians, it is the price of basic commodities that is creating uncertainty and concern. There have been protests over the rising cost of food.</div><div></div><br /><div>The worry for most Egyptians isn't the stock market, but the fruit and vegetable market.</div>
